docs.lead_paragraph: THE Connecticut River appears to be the dividing line for outbreaks of gypsy moth caterpillars this year. According to state entomologists, residents east of the river can expect the worst, while those who live west of the river and got the brunt of last year's defoliation will see less of it. These predictions are based on ongoing counts of the buff-colored egg masses that were laid by female moths last August. The eggs can be found on tree trunks, fence posts, stone walls, garbage cans and house shingles. Professional entomologists are still out in forests and woodlands completing egg counts. Dr. John F. Anderson, the State Entomologist and the head of the Department of Entomology at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven, said they had found a lot of egg masses east of the Connecticut River.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Congressional committee said today that most states had done an extremely poor job of policing Medicaid fraud, but that New York State had done a superlative job. The report by the House Select Committee on Aging concluded that ''state enforcement of the Medicaid program has been an unmitigated disaster'' except in New York. Elsewhere, it said, the deterrent effect of such enforcement is virtually nil. The study said that the states' poor record in dealing with Medicaid fraud raised serious questions about their ability to handle block grants and the numerous Federal programs that President Reagan wants to transfer to the states under his ''new federalism'' program.

headline.main: PANEL SAYS MOST STATES FAIL ON POLICING MEDICAID FRAUD
